story: It claims Airlander 10 will be able to take off and land on "virtually any flat surface" and visit locations which cannot be reached by existing transport methods.The aircraft will have no need for traditional infrastructure such as ports or airports, according to the company."Air travel has become very much about getting from A to B as quickly as possible. What we're offering is a way of making the journey a joy," HAV chief executive Stephen McGlennan said. The company believes Airlander 10 could be used for other functions other than leisure trips, including surveillance, communications, delivering aid and search and rescue missions.Used by the US army until 2016, it has been redesigned for domestic use and the 150ft-long cabin will accommodate up to 18 passengers and crew members for a three-day expedition.Its maximum speed is around 91mph - with the tourism-focused, eco-friendly aircraft being a leisurely voyage of the skies in comparison to the Airbus A380's cruising speed of 560mph.HAV say Airlander 10's design is practical and ready to go into production - with it being possible to customise it to individual customer requests.The aircraft's cockpit was severely damaged in August 2016 when it nose-dived and crashed during a test flight.It also collapsed in November last year after coming loose from its moorings - with both incidents occurring at its former base at Cardington Airfield, Bedfordshire.

title: grenfell emergency call operator relives
story: NewsGrenfell 999 operator relives comforting trapped girl, 12, until she 'heard her last gasps'Sarah Russell stayed on the phone for almost an hour to Jessica Urbano Ramirez, who called 999 complaining she could not escape due to the smoke.&nbspShareByMirror10:44, 19 JUL 2018Updated11:15, 19 JUL 2018NewsGrenfell Tower smoulders after an inferno ripped it apart (Image: PA)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA phone operator has described feeling completely helpless as she tried to comfort a trapped 12-year-old girl who died in the Grenfell Tower fire. Sarah Russell stayed on the phone for almost an hour to Jessica Urbano Ramirez, who called 999 complaining she could not escape due to the smoke. The girl told her she lived on the 20th floor but had taken refuge along with others higher up the tower block. Ms Russell said she answered the call, her first, at around 1.15am, and tried to get basic information from the little girl. In a written statement to the public inquiry, the London Fire Brigade control room officer said: I asked the girl what her name was and she told me it was Jessica.   'Whole community' raped girl, 12, for SEVEN MONTHS in latest horror attack in India  I asked Jessica if she was calling from her phone and I think she said she was. I asked to speak to someone a bit older to try and get some more information from them, but she did not hand it over I do not know why. Perhaps she did not want to. I felt I needed stay with her and that she needed me. I asked her if she wanted me to stay and she said 'yes'. I am glad I did - even if it was only to offer her a little support. The fact that she did not hand the phone to anyone else showed to me that she needed it. Ms Russell advised the very scared 12-year-old to go to the room least affected by smoke, shut the windows, stay low and cover her mouth. She went on: After about an hour I could not get anymore response from her - only rasping sounds, then nothing. I stayed on the line a little while longer with my hand hovered over the call termination button. I was torn as what best to do. I eventually ended the call when the line fell silent. Reflecting on that call, I felt completely helpless.  Met Police reveal Grenfell Tower fire MANSLAUGHTER prosecutions may be just around the corner    Grenfell campaigners stage dramatic walkout from Commons inquiry after accusing minister of lying  When people are pleading with you, saying do not want to die and I cannot physically do anything to help them it is very hard. I can pass on all the information but I cannot actually do anything - that is very tough. The information that Jessica had fled to a higher floor was not passed on to fire crews on the ground, who searched her flat but found no trace of the youngster. She was one of 72 people who died following the blaze on June 14 last year. Ms Russell revealed that, not long after the call ended, she became aware that the advice to callers had been changed from stay-put to attempt to evacuate. She said she did not recall ringing previous callers back with the changed advice, just answering the relentless calls and updating new callers. There was a lull in the calls at around 5am, Ms Russell said, recalling the words of a fellow operator. She said: It went eerily quiet and a little creepy. I remember someone saying, 'I wish they'd call again'. That way we would have known that they were still alive.

title: mps just voted keep corruption
story: NewsMPs just voted to keep corruption and sex harassment investigations into MPs secretThe list of MPs currently under investigation has already vanished from Parliament's website just minutes after today's decision in the House of Commons&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter16:09, 19 JUL 2018Updated16:46, 19 JUL 2018NewsStandards Commissioner probes into MPs will now be secret until they are concluded (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCurrent corruption and sex harassment probes into MPs will be kept secret after a landmark vote by MPs today. The list of MPs currently under investigation has already vanished from Parliament's website just minutes after today's decision in the House of Commons. It comes after MPs agreed the Parliamentary Standards Commissioner will no longer name MPs it is investigating - until that investigation finishes. Even then, in some cases the MP may not be named, even if they are found to be at fault. The watchdog probes MPs who are accused of using information for financial gain, having a conflict of interest or damaging the reputation and integrity of the House of Commons more generally.  Until this afternoon there was a current inquiries page on Parliament's website, which listed the names of MPs who were subject to ongoing probes. But that page has now vanished after MPs agreed the watchdog should no longer routinely publish information about individual investigations before those investigations are concluded. Backers said the move would ensure consistency and fairness because Parliament's new complaints scheme promises anonymity for both sides.   Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom said: We need a clear run at this, so we need confidentiality and we need consistency. But Green Party leader Caroline Lucas said: I think the optics of this house rolling back transparency is deeply deeply worrying. The proposals were backed by all parties. A direct bid to block the shake-up and keep names public was backed by just 22 MPs - while 79 voted not to block it.  Not a single Tory voted to block the shake-up. Twenty Labour MPs, independent John Woodcock and Green MP Caroline Lucas voted to block it. Seventy of the 79 MPs who voted for anonymity were Tories. Five were from Labour, including shadow equalities minister Dawn Butler. Three were Lib Dems and one was from the DUP . Under the new system, all current investigations by the Commissioner will be secret. If only the Commissioner was involved in an investigation, and not the new system, the MP involved will be named at the end of a probe - no matter what. If both the Commissioner and the new complaints scheme were involved, however, it is more complicated. MPs will not be named if the complaint was not upheld and if they weren't named in the press. Even if the complaint was upheld, the Commissioner will have regard for proportion and the MP's reputation, as well as any desire for anonymity by the complainant, before deciding whether to publish.

title: tory esther mcvey denies universal
story: NewsTory Esther McVey DENIES Universal Credit has been too brutal - despite revealing yet more climbdowns to comeThe Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is "working on" changes that are "still needed" to the six-in-one welfare system - five years after it launched&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter13:52, 19 JUL 2018Updated14:28, 19 JUL 2018NewsThe Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is working on changes that are still needed to the six-in-one welfare system - five years after it launched (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory welfare chief Esther McVey today flatly denied Universal Credit has been too brutal - despite unveiling yet more climbdowns over the flagship benefit. The Work and Pensions Secretary admitted she is working on changes that are still needed to the six-in-one welfare system - five years and a million claimants after it launched. They include more support for the self-employed and possible changes to the taper rate to let people keep more of the money they earn. But she refused to say the system had been flawed - or if she backs ex-welfare chief Iain Duncan Smith's call to pump in &pound2billion a year more. Mr Duncan Smith made his call after money was sucked out of the system before it launched in a move that will leave hundreds of thousands of families worse off. Asked by the Mirror if her climbdowns showed the system as rolled out was too harsh or brutal, she said: It was very very slow as we rolled it out so we were monitoring as we were rolled it out. So no, it wasn't, and we've stopped and changed it as we went along.  What is right is we continue to learn and change. Some &pound1.5billion was put into Universal Credit to make it fairer at last year's Budget, and further cash will be approved for people with severe disabilities. But in May Iain Duncan Smith, who held the job for six years before quitting over one benefit cut too far, called for &pound2billion more a year for UC on top of that. Ms McVey avoided saying whether she backed Mr Duncan Smith. Instead she pointed out the cash that had already been put in. In a speech to charities and campaigners at the Reform think tank, Ms McVey pleaded for their ideas to improve the benefit - despite it being in its sixth year. UC's rollout was blasted by the National Audit Office, pitching her into a public row with the watchdog when she was accused of misrepresenting its findings.  But Ms McVey said: We need to reach out to, learn from organisations such as yourselves, and yes, that includes the National Audit Office, about how to design and implement Universal Credit to support claimants. We want to work with you to understand where we can improve on this important reform. And there are changes that are still needed which I'm working on. Debt repayments, support for the self-employed, payment cycles for those in work, and an extension of outreach work and an extension of flexible support for claimants. Campaigners have warned self-employed workers face being crushed by UC because they are barred from claiming any more benefits than if they earned minimum wage. Ms McVey also signalled she could cut the 'taper rate', the amount of benefit taken away for every pound earned, further after it reduced from 65p to 63p. She said: If we can, yes we would look to reduce that.

title: exmoor beast giant cat size
story: News'Exmoor Beast' giant cat the size of LABRADOR dog with two foot-long tail jumps out in front of driverDavid Gliddon, 72, from Williton in Somerset, said the big feline creature leapt onto a wall in front of him while he was driving between Trentishoe and Heddon's Mouth in Devon&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJoel Cooper13:17, 19 JUL 2018Updated13:19, 19 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man has described the jaw-dropping moment a giant cat jumped out in front of him while driving his car on a road in Devon. In jaw-dropping scenes, David Gliddon, 72, said the big feline creature leapt onto a wall in front of him while he was driving between Trentishoe and Heddon's Mouth on Exmoor. While he failed to take a photo, the sighting comes amid reports of others claiming they have seen evidence of the so called 'Exmoor Beast'.  David, from Williton in Somerset, described the cat as a great big thing with a thick, two foot long tail - and told DevonLive that the experience had left him dumbstruck.  He had been walking near Hunter's Inn on July 4 with his daughter prior to the sighting. It was the size of a large Labrador, or possibly bigger, he said.  It jumped up onto a wall about five yards in front of me on the road, the way it moved was just like a cat. Its tail was about two foot long and very thick, a constant width from start to finish. It was a browny greyish colour with slightly lighter, almost green flecks or spots. It was only there for an instant before it jumped over the other side of the wall. Stunned, David stopped the car in the middle of the road and ran to the wall to see if the animal was still there. He said: When I looked over the wall it looked like it had run off into the thick bracken.  I have never seen anything like this before. It was so clear. I was dumbstruck, I could not believe what I had seen. David, a keen wildlife watcher, says he is aware of wild mink and terrapins in this area, and the pythons and wallaby have also been spotted previously in West Somerset. He said: I've always kept an open mind. I've been on safari in Africa and seen a leopard from a distance, and this animal very similar in its characteristics. It was a jaw-dropping experience. I'd like to know if any farmers in that area have lost any sheep recently or if anyone else has spotted anything similar.

title: familys holiday nightmare passengers fainted
story: NewsFamily's holiday nightmare as 'passengers fainted and had panic attacks' on sweltering Thomas Cook plane stuck on tarmac for HOURSBekki Reece says conditions became so bad her 12-year-old daughter suffered a nose bleed, while her one-year-old girl was fanned by other travellers as temperatures soared&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMatt Jackson06:50, 19 JUL 2018Updated09:03, 19 JUL 2018NewsBekki Reece and partner Shane Davies were travelling back from Lanzarote (Image: Stoke Sentinel WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A family says their dream holiday turned into a nightmare as passengers fainted and had panic attacks on a sweltering Thomas Cook plane which was stuck on the tarmac for three hours waiting for take off.  Bekki Reece says conditions became so bad her 12-year-old daughter suffered a nose bleed, while her one-year-old girl was fanned by other travellers as temperatures soared to about 37C. The 32-year-old, from Biddulph, Staffordshire, says there was no air-con or water available as the plane sat waiting. Bekki, partner Shane Davies and her three young children were among 300 passengers trapped on the packed jet at Lanzarote airport.  She told the Stoke Sentinel conditions caused some to faint, suffer panic attacks and vomit as the smell of aviation fuel filled the cabin.   The family had been due to fly back with Thomas Cook to Manchester at 8.20pm on Thursday, July 5 but arrived at the airport only to be told they faced a two-and-a-half hour delay because of technical issues.   Bekki, who was also joined on the flight by mum Deb Dale and step-dad Michael Dale, said: “We got to the check-in and were told it would be a two-and-a-half hour delay but then at the gate it said three. We eventually boarded the plane but when we got on it was stifling - Shane said he felt sick. “After two hours my eldest daughter was having nose bleeds and my youngest looked as though she had just got out the bath because she was dripping with sweat. Passengers were using their safety cards to fan her down. It was really scary. She was so floppy and struggling to keep awake. “They opened the doors but there was a lot of commotion and after about three hours a young girl fainted. “I was worried for all our health - it was unbearable. Any longer and we would have all passed out.” Bekki, who also has a nine-year-old daughter, added: “Eventually the plane was taken back to the runway at 12.15am but we were told that under Lanzarote laws planes can’t take off after midnight.”

title: how brave eight year old
story: NewsHow brave eight-year-old girl 'project managed' her own death - then 'led parents to perfect Center Parcs-like grave'EXCLUSIVE: Little Kaleigh Lau's family regularly have picnics at her resting place after she died from a rare brain cancer last month - they say: "There's no sadness around there, it feels like Center Parcs"&nbspShare&nbspCommentsBySophie Evans15:32, 19 JUL 2018Updated15:44, 19 JUL 2018NewsLittle Kaleigh Lau died peacefully surrounded by her parents and six-year-old brother last month (Image: Mirrorpix)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave eight-year-old girl 'project managed' her own death so her loved ones could visit and say a final goodbye, her grieving family say.  Little Kaleigh Lau died peacefully surrounded by her parents and six-year-old brother last month after battling a rare brain cancer .  Her dad, Scott, believes she prepared everybody for her passing by falling into a deep 'sleep' before she took her final breaths. During this time, he says all of her loved ones were able to visit her - and it was only once they had, that she decided time is up. But even on the day she died, Kaleigh's condition changed dramatically as her gran, aunt and uncle raced down the country to see her.  Despite being up and down in the early hours of that morning, she became stable as her relatives began the heartbreaking journey.  She remained this way until they arrived at hospital several hours later.  Once they had, she quickly deteriorated and passed away. Kaleigh was the ultimate project manager, Scott, 42, told . She was preparing everybody for her death. She was in a sleep and everybody went to visit her who wanted to visit her. That's when she started to say, 'Time is up'. The proud dad, who works as a project manager himself, added that he and his wife, Yang, alerted his in-laws to Kaleigh's condition on June 12.  After being joined at the hospital by their son Carson and Scott's mother at 3am, he said they sent a message to Yang's family in Manchester. They saw the message at 5am, started the journey at 5.30am, he said. Kaleigh was up and down during the night. Her stats became stable until the in-laws arrived at 8.30am, then they went up and down. It was at around 9.20am, less than an hour after her beloved relatives successfully made the trip down South, that 'princess' Kaleigh died. She was one of the longest-surviving UK patients with Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG), an inoperable paediatric brain tumour. She had been diagnosed with the deadly condition - which affects around 40 children every year and currently has no cure - in April 2016.  At the time, she was expected to live for only nine months. But defying medics' predictions, the little girl survived for more than two years. Following her death, she was cremated in a lovely service, which was carried out in Kaleigh's way and attended by hundreds of people. A beautiful celebration of life was later held in her honour. And as well as 'project managing' her own death, the youngster's family believe she 'guided' them to the perfect spot to bury her ashes. Even looking for her final resting place, she guided us all the way, said Scott, from Woodford Green, East London. We would have never imagined the place we did. Kaleigh's family had looked around several potential burial sites, but nothing was quite her. They then visited GreenAcres woodland cemetery.  In the corner of my eye, I spotted a tree in the middle of the green. The manager had never even seen that tree, recalled Scott. We said, 'Could Kaleigh be laid to rest here?' His daughter, who was treated at the capital's Great Ormond Street Hospital, now rests under the tree at the cemetery near Epping. Her ashes are buried near a pond, so she can feed the ducks, and are surrounded by grass moulds, which she can roll around on. It's so peaceful, she's the only one on the green, said her dad. We take our picnics down there and sit there to talk to her. Ahead of Kaleigh's celebration of life, her parents had taken little brother Carson to GreenAcres to show him his sister's resting place. We took him there before she was laid to rest, said Scott.  He was playing on his tablet and playing around. There's no sadness around there. It feels like Center Parcs, it feels like a golf course. He added that he and Yang, 38, didn't tell their son the full extent of his sibling's condition, saying: We didn't tell him the severity. He continued: Carson has been undergoing counselling. We told him everybody will go to Heaven one day. We told him his sister has gone off to do another mission - and that 'Your sister will always love you and you can talk to her whenever you want'. Kaleigh, who enjoyed being a 'princess' and dancing, was diagnosed with DIPG after she complained of double vision following a cold. Her parents were eating breakfast with her at home when she suddenly laughed and told them that she could see two of them.  Concerned, they then noticed her left eye was turning slightly inwards. After seeking advice from an optician pal, the couple took their daughter to Moorfields Eye Hospital, where her double vision was confirmed. Specialists said the youngster's eye looked healthy, but told Scott and Yang that she should get checked out at a general hospital. Kaleigh was then taken to the Royal London Hospital, where a CT scan was carried out, followed by an MRI scan five hours later.  They explained the CT scan would happen today, Scott explained in an interview about his daughter with  last year.  But as it was a Saturday the MRI would be done on Monday. When the hospital called for the MRI team to come in that night I knew what they saw on the CT scan wasn't good. On Sunday, the consultants came round and told us not to worry as on Tuesday they would tell us what the treatment plan would be.  Tuesday came and that was when our world started to cave in and turned upside down. Scott and his wife were left horrified by their little girl's DIPG diagnosis. When I asked when do they operate, they said they couldn't, said Scott. When asked what we could do, they said radiotherapy. Once we left the room, we looked it up on the web and the statistics were just something that you couldn't imagine. He added that although he and Yang were told there was no known cure for the disease, they clung on to any glimmer of hope possible. Kaleigh underwent 30 sessions of radiotherapy followed by an eight-month honeymoond period before her double vision returned. She subsequently underwent a second round of radiotherapy, comprising 10 further treatments in January and February last year.  However, her double vision remained and she began suffering from a weak left hand, stuttering speech and very unbalanced walking. She also started experiencing more regular headaches. Her desperate parents took her to Mexico with Carson last April for intraarterial chemotherapy and immunotherapy experimental treatment. Kaleigh is the first foreign overseas patient in the world to receive this combination of treatment, Scott explained last year. The family returned from the Mexican facility, but flew back a number of times so that Kaleigh could undergo further treatment. This treatment was self-funded, costing tens of thousands of pounds, and still at an experimental stage, with no guarantees. But after the first and second rounds, the youngster was able to swim, do the monkey bars, hop on one foot and perform cartwheels. The size of her tumour was also reduced.  In January and March this year, Kaleigh travelled to the facility again. Her most recent trip was due to take place in May. However, the journey had to be postponed because she was too unwell. We knew that the only chance we ever really had was Mexico, Scott said. Even the day before we were due to fly, I was still adamant that we had to go, but at the last minute we pulled the plug. Kaleigh just wasn't well enough. The little girl then underwent a MRI scan and blood tests in the UK. The day before she fell into a deep unconscious state, she was still smiling, even giving a thumbs up to the medic taking her blood. But while being checked over by nurses and mummy, she suffered an internal haemorrhage inside her tumour and her heart rate dropped. She spent six weeks 'sleeping' in a coma until she passed away.  Scott said that while he has seen a lot of very cruel ways that children with DIPG pass away, his daughter had a peaceful death. Carson was in the room when she died, he added. Kaleigh was carried to her celebration of life by her doting mum. Her ashes were stored in a small box, featuring the words: Team Kaleigh. The celebration, which was captured in a series of stunning pictures by photographer David Solomans, was attended by 300 to 400 people. Attendees included family, friends, doctors, nurses and Bradley Lowery Foundation co-founder Lynn Murphy, who made a moving speech. It was amazing, just perfect, said Scott. He added that since the ceremony, loved ones have received a lot of signs that his daughter has reached her destination. The little girl loved coin pushers, with one family friend even bringing a machine to her when she couldn't travel to the seaside anymore.

title: meghan markles close friend claims
story: NewsMeghan Markle's close friend claims 'story' about Duchess's dad's heart surgery was 'made up' so he could avoid royal weddingThomas Markle pulled out of his daughter's wedding just days after it emerged he had been paid to pose for pictures of his shopping for a wedding outfit and looking at pictured of Meghan and Harry&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAbigail O'Leary08:59, 19 JUL 2018Updated11:14, 19 JUL 2018NewsThomas Markle says he hasn't spoken to his daughter in two months (Image: Daily Mirror)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeghan Markle's close friend has slammed the Duchess's dad, Thomas Markle, claiming his heart surgery was 'all made up' after his embarrassing staged photo shoot. It was later revealed the 73-year-old had suffered a heart attack and was undergoing heart surgery. Now, a source close to the Duchess of Sussex has branded his heart surgery as a 'story', fabricated as a way out of the wedding. They said: The whole story about Meghan's father undergoing heart surgery was made up. He had to come up with a good enough reason not to attend her wedding and avoid any further embarrassment after those staged photos went public., reports the Mail Online.   Meghan Markle's dad Thomas vows he won't stop speaking to the media until Royals 'break their silence'  The source added people should 'feel sorry for Meghan' as opposed to her father. Appearing on Good Morning Britain, Thomas, a former film lighting director, said he had checked into the Sharp Chula Vista Medical Center, north of the Mexican border. The hospital has since said 'no such name' was on their patient records. Thomas Markle has also said he won't stop speaking to the media until the Royals break their silence. He said he's unfazed by reports that the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are growing 'frustrated' with his recent outspoken interviews about Meghan.   Meghan Markle and Prince Harry field VERY cheeky question from royal fan with the best comeback  Thomas told TMZ he simply wants to make peace with his estranged daughter. He said: I was silent for a full year and the press beat me up every day saying I was a hermit hiding in Mexico, so I gave my story. Apparently that interview put the Royal Family in their silence mode ... so, I gave another interview to break the silence. All they have to do is speak to me.” Thomas Markle also said that he is amused that he can force the Royal Family into a media blackout. Tomorrow [Wednesday] is my birthday, 74 years old, and I’m enjoying the fact that I can make the entire Royal Family not speak and maybe I can get a laugh out of the Duchess.   Thomas Markle 'wants to fly to the UK to make peace with Meghan' - days after saying she's hiding behind 'fake smile'  Mr. Markle has given numerous interviews in recent months, including a paid interview with the Sun in which he revealed his daughter hasn't returned his calls for over two months.
